title: Bcon 147: Special topics in business economics
text:
Class schedule: Tuesday | 13:00 - 16:00  Instructor: Christopher Llones  e-mail: christopher.llones@vsu.edu.ph  Course credits: 3 units  Number of hours: 3 hrs lectures 


Course description
This course provides Business Economics majors with the necessary skills for advanced data analytics and visualization using R programming.


Course objectives

Develop proficiency in R programming with an emphasis on data wrangling and visualization.
Apply advanced data analysis techniques to business economics problems.
Design and interpret data visualizations that communicate insights effectively.
Handle real-world economic datasets and make data-driven decisions.
Complete a comprehensive capstone project that integrates course concepts.



Course outline








Topics
Lessons
Description




Module 1: Introduction to R programming

Overview of R programming and its application
Introduction to R syntax, data types and structures
Reading data into R
Basic R operation and data manipulation


Understand the role of R in data analytics for business economics.
Set up and understand R data types and structures.
Importing and cleaning data.
Perform basic operation and data management with R.



Module 2: Reproducible analysis in R

Introduction to reproducibility in research
Setting up and working with Quarto for reproducible reporting
Integrating code, text and visualization in quarto document
Hosting and publishing reports on GitHub


Understand the importance of reproducibility in data analysis
Set up and use Quarto to create reproducible reports.
Generate report with embedded code, text, and visualization in Quarto document.
Generate and publish online reports hosted in GitHub.



Module 3: Data wrangling with R

Introduction to data wrangling and manipulation
Data manipulation and reshaping
Data merging and joining
String manipulation and text processing.


Grasps the importance of data wrangling in the analysis process.
Apply functions to wrangle and summarize data.
Merge and join dataset efficiently.
Wrangle and clean textual data.



Module 4: Introduction to data visualization with ggplot2

The ggplot2 grammar of graphics.
Dataset and mapping
Geometries
Statistical transformation and plotting distribution
Position and adjustment scales
Coordinates and themes
Facets and custom plots


Understand the core principles of data visualization and its significance.
Use ggplot2 package to create foundation plot.
Customize visualizations
Develop effective visualizations to communicate data insights.



Module 5: EDA and visualizing relationships and trends

Summary statistics and visualizing distribution.
Correlation and regression visualizations.
Interactive visualization with plotly.


Perform summary statistics and visualizations to explore data.
Visualize and interpret relationships between variables.
Explore the basics of interactive visualizations using plotly.



Module 6: Cluster analysis and principal component analysis (PCA)

Introduction to cluster analysis and techniques.
Introduction to principal component analysis.
Cluster analysis and PCA applications.
Reporting and communicating cluster and PCA results.


Understand the fundamental concepts of cluster analysis and its techniques (e.g., K-mean, hierarchical)
Understand the principles of PCA for dimensionality reduction.
Apply cluster analysis and PCA to real-world business economics problems.
Develop skills to effectively communicate findings of cluster analysis and PCA.



Model 7: Structural equation modeling

Introduction to SEM.
Building SEM models: path diagrams and model specifications.
Model specification and estimation for CB and PLS SEM models.
Model evaluation and diagnostics.


Understand the fundamental concepts of SEM.
Learn how to create path diagrams in SEM.
Learn model specification and apply estimation methods to fit CB and PLS SEM models.
Evaluate and conduct diagnostics for model specifications and overall fit.



Module 8: Introduction to text analysis

Introduction to text data and its significance in business economics.
Text processing: tokenization, stemming, and stop-word
Introduction to sentiment analysis
Visualizing textual data


Understand the role of text analysis in business economics.
Learn how to preprocess textual data for analysis.
Conduct sentiment analysis.
Visualize text data insights.



Module 9: Time series and forecasting

Time series decomposition and visualization.
Smoothing techniques
Forecasting
Visualizing forecasts and uncertainty.


Decompose and visualize time series data components.
Apply smoothing techniques to analyze trends and seasonality.
Use time series models to forecasts economic indicators.
Visualize forecasts results and communicate uncertainty.

Install R and RStudio on your computer.
Download the entire folder 00-module-intro-r from the Google Drive link. For the meantime, keep the folder in your computer and wait for further instructions during the class.
Before the class start, open the RStudio and paste the following code in the console to install the required packages. Just click the clipboard icon to copy the code.


## install required packages
install.packages(c("janitor", "readxl", "haven", "tidyverse", "skimr"))







Important



Please make sure to install the required packages before the class starts, as we may not have a secure internet connection. If you encounter any issues, please let me know.

title: Intro to data visualization using ggplot2
text:
Class demonstration
# libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(babynames)

## select names
friends <- babynames %>% 
  filter(year >= 1950,
         name %in% c("Christopher", "Dave", "Karl"),
         sex == "M")

## plotting trends
ggplot(data = friends,
       mapping = aes(x = year, y = n, color = name)) +
  geom_line(linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_point(size = 4, alpha = 0.5) +
  scale_y_log10() +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 24),
        axis.text = element_text(size = 16),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 16),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 18)
        )










# libraries
library(tidyverse)

## calculating mean hwy per class
mean_hwy_data <- mpg %>% 
  group_by(class) %>% 
  summarise(mean_hwy = mean(hwy, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(data = mpg,
       mapping = aes(x = class, y = hwy, color = class)) +
  geom_point(position = "jitter", size = 3, alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_point(data = mean_hwy_data, aes(y = mean_hwy), size = 7) +
  labs(title = "Fuel consumption per class vehicle",
       x = "Class of vehicle",
       y = "Highway fuel consumption") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 24),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 24),
        axis.text = element_text(size = 16),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 16),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 18)
        )










## libraries
library(tidyverse)

## histogram plot

ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 10, fill = "cadetblue3", alpha = 0.5) + 
  geom_text(aes(label = after_stat(count)),
            stat = "bin", 
            bins = 10, 
            nudge_y = 2) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text = element_text(size = 14),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 16),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 14),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 16)
        )
